of bootloader security my name is Fie i'm part of a group in Google Cloud that
actually performs low-level attacks on hardware and firmware
and um I usually do this by basically doing a penetration test that means I get all sorts of devices and I get to
open them up i you know study the PCBs uh look at each chip try and reverse
engineer firmware and um basically try and uncover any lowlevel

that we can actually exploit um that's useful for demonstrating risk and the
idea there is that hopefully you know we can we can report these and and and uh
you know find these vulnerabilities and report them responsibly that's that's the idea but um these vulnerabilities
are actually a little bit different than regular software vulnerabilities so let me say a couple words on the context in
which they're exploitable so if you have an embedded device or just any device really you
have a supply chain right because your device has to be manufactured it has to be built and it consists of parts that
you know come together and when that all has happened it's actually shipped and
there's a lot of hands touching the device even before it is actually deployed that means attackers will have
time limited access but they will have physical access to the device and time limited in this sense can already be in
the order of days so you can pull off quite a lot of um nice hardware and firmware attacks during that time and
then even when it's deployed and you know even assuming you have a perfect supply chain there's legitimate use
cases to access the device either remotely with credentials or physically to do some repairs maybe um so in that
case attackers might also be able to physically access the device and perform some attacks and it it gets even more
interesting if you consider bare metal clouds um offerings in these scenarios you know
there's nothing that stands you know between an attacker that's already privileged on the device and um you know
they might want to mess with the hardware and firmware a bit uh so what's important in these scenarios is that you
can actually bring back the device into a trustworthy state that's what we're trying to do that's why we need hardware
security and of course once the tenant leaves the device you also want to make sure that you can return the device into
a trustworthy state and um you know there's many definitions of trustworthy
but for sure what you want to avoid is um some persistence um persistence in
firmware persistence in in flash or or peripheral devices and um I find this
work very interesting um I will show some of our findings to you today
um all of this has of course been reported responsibly our idea is that this low-level perspective can
contribute to all of the other good stuff that's already happening in the security community and standard bodies

published and I actually you know um would like to thank everyone who's worked on this and allow me to present
my findings here today so I said bottom up right we we open up
devices we start with um looking at chips at debugging interfaces and and

um bootloaders often have a security critical role in all sorts of
devices and um yeah we will have a look at this i will basically show you two
critical vulnerabilities that I identified and then I'm going to tell you how to fix it all because I I hope
that we'll be interested in fixing it and um I think this is actually a good chance to do so across a wide range of
devices and um just some fun facts for you we have reviewed more than 15
different device types and these devices were using open source bootloaders and all of them have been affected by
bootloader vulnerabilities at some point what does that mean um a bootloader
vulnerability in this case would have allowed an attacker to gain code execution in the bootloader context
that's usually very very privileged and um basically allows you to compromise all further boot stages or the operating
system and I think this is a concern um I I hope this is a chance for me to you
know present this and and point at the gaps that I can see and um show you some of the examples now you might be

so this is a wide range and I'm actually convinced that the bootloaders um um
that that we will talk about here uh will actually extend and cover a wider range of devices like IoT and cars and
most likely um you will be recognizing some of these open source bootloaders as
well now I will kick this off with one of the first vulnerabilities that I found in in Cisco devices so this is
um a Cisco Nexus N9000 series switch there's different variations different
port counts but um inside they all look uh similar if you open them up um
because there's a lot of specialized hardware like um AS6 that handle network traffic of course but it's all
bootstrapped by this what I call the management board uh shown here on the right hand picture so in this picture
you should be able to see an SSD down there and under the heat sink there's an
Intel processor and um Cisco actually invested you know some resources there
and hardened the boot chain so this device has a secure boot chain it has a root of trust chip and um yeah you could
consider it state-of-the-art um in my opinion and um well of course I as an
attacker don't like this i want to run my own software on this i want to run Doom or whatever and um since it's an
Intel processor I would expect to find Intel firmware and actually that's what I did so I took out the mainboard turned
it around and there it is there you have your uh small SPI flash chip this is um
very common in these types of devices and uh when you dump it and open it in UFI tool you find that this is a
firmware volume there's a couple firmware volumes on there with all sorts of drivers and EDK2-based firmware and
one of them is actually called Cisco Grub and since I already knew they had implemented secure boot I thought maybe
Cisco Grub actually is the bootloadader and maybe it's involved in you know enforcing secure boot and and uh
signature checks for the operating system image so I fired up Gedra loaded up um this this binary and what I found
were some strings that seemed a little odd right and uh it actually seemed like
they had just taken Grub but I expected to see Grup 2 which is like the modern version of it and and the one that all
Linux distribution use nowadays but instead um after googling some of the strings I found that they had actually
forked Grap Legacy the one from the '9s and um that was that was surprising so
then I thought you know how on earth did they actually implement secure boot with
such an old bootloader grub legacy didn't support secure boot so the way that this works is um Cisco Grub will
identify all kinds of boot devices this is mostly the internal flash that you um
saw on the previous image but it could also be a USB drive that you plug into the front of the device and once it's
identified a bootable device it will try and identify OS images they always kind of look the same and have some
signatures on them and um once it's loaded an operating system image it will verify the signature and execute it if
it's if it's proper this first part here this
actually requires interacting with a file system and the way that this is
commonly solved today in modern firmware is that you use EDK2 or load image which
which you know hooks into the EFI firmware where someone else has implemented a way to interact with some
file system and load a file but Gra Legacy didn't have all that because it's
from the '9s right so they implemented all kinds of file system drivers and what actually happens here is that
there's a big loop that basically brute forces all available file system backends and the first one that mounts
successfully will actually be used to try and find an operating system
image my idea was maybe I can find a bug in such a file system because at the
time they had around 12 or 13 like u random file systems like even Riser FS
so I thought okay there might be actually a chance for me to find a vulnerability and looking at the XFS
driver um I found this function that's responsible for listing files and here
you can see there's this link buff stuck allocated buffer that um has a size and
its size is controlled by a variable in the super block and you need to remember that the superb block is actually stored
externally it's stored on a USB drive or the internal SSD and of course if I have
physical access or maybe even remote access with a root shell you know I can just modify that super block set its
size to zero which will make the next uh length check here uh succeed and end up
calling me copy into my zero size link buff buffer with an attacker controlled
size so this is a textbook example of a buffer overflow uh of course there's no
exploit mitigations or anything like that and um I think there's two scenarios in which you can exploit this
the first one is um what I have hinted at already like you can plug a USB drive
that you prepared into the front of the device that's shown here on this picture
and um you know just walk up to it plug it in and the next time the device will reboot it could trigger the
vulnerability or you could do that remotely you know maybe you have administrative credentials or another
vulnerability you can get a shell this is actually a feature you can just ask the device to give you a shell and uh
then use that shell to write the malicious XFF partition to disk and reboot and what happens then is that
Grup will or Cisco Grub will open a well-known file and you can use that to exploit debuffer overflow get code
execution bypass the signature checks and so on uh if you actually do this it would
look similar to this i did this for demonstration purposes here this is actually in an emulator where you get a
nice register dump at the end but um basically I set the storage device i
list a file and this triggers the buffer overflow in the XFS file system back
end cool um what does this allow you to do you
get um you know code execution in the context of Cisco Grap that's very privileged there's no exploit
mitigations i find this very hard to detect honestly because the device doesn't really give you that many ways
that you could detect an attack like that yes they have a root of trust chip but um you know even if it did gather
like me measurements or hashes of the firmware and stores them in a safe place there's no software interface that you
can use to interface with that root of trust chip uh yet and um also all
recovery functions that this device provides are based or implemented in either GRUP
itself maybe some other drivers but that's unlikely or most of it actually lives in in the Linux operating system
that is started after you already compromised GROP so if you're smart about it you could potentially uh try

a lot of the business logic um a first stage bootloader basically
has one job and that is to bring the system into a state where a more capable bootloader can execute so this function

memory in an SPI flash loaded into DRAM verify its signature and then

you know secure boot is nice but over time there will be bugs in any firmware
in in in any bootloader perhaps and it's important that we actually have a way to

downgrade protection could help us prevent an attacker with physical access to just flash back the old vulnerable

all of them have been fixed but you know without downgrade protection or some of the other stuff that I'll show it's

it there's possibly other um cases that you know actually lead you to want to
downgrade so it would be nice if this was configurable as a user um currently
this is not the case with any device that we have reviewed another option that would allow
you to manage your firmware um vulnerability footprint or version footprint would be remote at a station
so secure boot works in the way that one stage verifies the next one that's simple if the next stage signature
doesn't match if there's something wrong going on um it would just not execute that and um this is an important
property this is strong but at the end if the device actually boots you kind of
need to infer that it's in a trustworthy state just from the fact that it booted and I think that's that's a little weak
i think that it could be better and remote editation is one way that you can use to address this you can have each
stage not just verify the signature of the next stage you can still do that if
you like but instead in in what's called measured boot each stage would collect
some evidence of whatever configuration or binary it executes next and this
evidence it's usually a hash that you put in a temper resistant environment
like a root of trust chip or security chip some area in your SSC whatever and
combined with an identity the cryptographic identity you can create proof and this proof can then be m uh
you know maybe challenged with some freshness and then used by your credential infrastructure to not just
get some evidence of what versions and and what types of fmer and binaries you're running in your fleet but also um
you know see if a downgrade actually happens because often you just see the changes and it's it's not easy to
predict um what type of evidence you have you know at the end of the day you just have a bunch of hashes so there's a
lot of practical um hurdles with this and um maybe one way that we can improve
this is by asking vendors to actually make this usable in almost all devices that we reviewed it's actually not
usable even though the hardware theoretically supports it and then if it is usable it would be nice if it was
usable for everyone and not just you know large enterprises um who already have some kind of
